body:
Comment 3: 
The /etc/resolv.conf error is just a playground implementation detail; it could provide
e.g. "localhost".

On re-reading the text on the right side of http://tour.golang.org/#3 I realize that the
networking sentence could be clearer -- sandbox can fake-network to itself.

Maybe replace

> The playground can use most of the standard library, with some exceptions; notably
absent are network and file system access. Therefore, the only communication a
playground program has to the outside world is by writing to standard output and
standard error.

With something like

> The playground can use most of the standard library, with some exceptions; notably
absent are network and file system access. Therefore, the only communication a
playground program has to the outside world is by writing to standard output and
standard error. The only network host reachable is 127.0.0.1, where the server and
client run in the same application but in different goroutines.
